block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. Free with village admission. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; hours change in July. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.
ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to the 19th centuries, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. Free with village admission. The exhibition ''Toys!'' will run through December 2001. Guided tours are available. Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m.; hours change in July. Admission: $4; the elderly and children 6 to 18, and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

INTREPID SEA-AIR-SPACE MUSEUM, Pier 86, West 46th Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A converted World War II aircraft carrier with two full decks of displays, including four theme halls: United States Navy Hall, Pioneer Hall, Technologies Hall and Intrepid Hall. ''Prepare to Dive: The 100th Anniversary of the Navy's First Submarine,'' an exhibition about the pioneering days of the submarine. ''Mission Control: From the Space Race to the Space Shuttle,'' an interactive exhibition exploring the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo projects as well as the current shuttle program. Admission: $12; the elderly, veterans, reservists and ages 12 to 17, $9; ages 2 to 5, $2; under 2, free; wheelchair patrons, half price. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Information: (212) 245-0072.

LOWER EAST SIDE TENEMENT MUSEUM, 90 Orchard Street, at Broome Street. A look at the urban immigrant experience. The museum includes a partly restored tenement at 97 Orchard Street. ''Firecrackers: Chinatown Today,'' photographic works by Andrew Garn mounted on light boxes; through June 20. Children can explore an apartment that was once home to the Confino family and interact with an actor playing a 13-year-old family member, Saturdays and Sundays at noon and 1, 2 and 3 p.m. In another apartment, visitors can experience the Jewish rite of mourning, sitting shiva with the Rogarshevsky family. These and the museum's two other apartments, which housed the Gumpertz and Baldizzi families, can be viewed on guided tours. Guided tours: Tuesdays through Fridays at 1, 2, 3 and 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m. until the last tour at 4:30 p.m. Suggested donation: $3. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Free. Tour prices: $9; students, the elderly and children over 5, $7; children 5 and under, free. Special prices for two and three tours. Information: (212) 431-0233.

MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, Fifth Avenue at 103rd Street. ''New York Now 2000: Contemporary Work in Photography,'' through Oct. 15. ''Ordinary People, Extraordinary Lives: 100 Years of Labor in New York City,'' a tribute to New York's working people, through July 16. ''Under the El, City Life in 20th-Century Prints and Drawings,'' through Dec. 3. ''Elegant Plate: 300 Years of Precious Metals in New York,'' through Sept. 24. ''Noel Coward Centennial,'' through Nov. 5. ''The New York Century: World Capital, Hometown,'' through Feb. 4. Sunday at 2 p.m., The filmmaker Brent Sterling, whose series of documentaries for PBS, ''Souls of the City,'' are on view in the exhibition ''New York Century,'' and the columnist Toni Schlesinger interview some New Yorkers with interesting jobs they have profiled. ''A Tribute to Patricia Zipprodt,'' the costume designer, through July 2. ''New York: Songs of the City,'' through Sept. 10. Hours: Tuesdays 10 a.m. to 2 p.m., for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Suggested admission: $7; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $12. Information: (212) 534-1672.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts and exhibitions in other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. ''Mary Hartman, Mary Hartman: Marathon, Marathon,'' through Sept. 3. Screenings Tuesdays through Sundays, 2 p.m.; also Thursdays at 6 p.m. and Fridays at 7 p.m. ''Something for Everyone: Sondheim Tonight,'' a retrospective commemorating the composer's 70th birthday. Daily screenings, Tuesdays through Sundays at 2 p.m.; also Thursdays at 5:30 and Fridays at 6:30 p.m.; through July 2. Tonight at 6:30, ''Pacific Overtures,'' taped for Japanese television during its original 1976 Broadway run. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 13 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Stork Club,'' including an environmental installation that mimics the floor plan of the club, photographs and memorabilia belonging to the family of Sherman Billingsley, the owner of the club; on view through Oct. 1. ''Magnum, Our Turning World: Photographs, 1989-1999,'' through June 18. ''New York Inside Out,'' an exhibition portraying New Yorkers at home; through Aug. 20. ''Jesse Tarbox Beals: On Assignment,'' photographs, through July 2. ''Without Sanctuary: Lynching Photography in America,'' images from the 1870's through the 1950's, through Aug. 13. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a panel discussion with historians about the exhibition ''Without Sanctuary.'' ''The Changing Face of Liberty: Female Allegories of America,'' featuring color lithographs, posters, political cartoons and drawings; through Sept. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
Cruises

WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the West Side of Manhattan and around New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 p.m., boarding at 6 p.m. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 p.m., with boarding at 11:30 a.m. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.

N.Y. WATERWAY, leaving from Pier 78, West 38th Street and 12th Avenue, Manhattan. Daily two-hour full Manhattan cruise, at 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., through Nov. 12. Tickets: $24; $19 for the elderly; $12 for children ages 3 to 12; 2 and younger, free. Daily, a 90-minute cruise of New York Harbor; at 10 a.m., noon, 2 and 4 p.m. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; ages 3 to 12, $9; 2 and younger, free. Fridays at 10:15 p.m., Disco cruise. Price: $19; $9 for children. A 70-minute twilight tour leaves daily, except Tuesday, at 8:45 p.m.; additional tours on Saturdays at 7:15 and 10:15 p.m. and on Sundays at 7:15. Tickets: $19; the elderly, $16; children, $9. Information: (800) 533-3779.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. The roses are in peak bloom through June. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden has recently reopened; with specially guided tours (hourly from 1 to 4 p.m.), programs and events through June 18. Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., ceremonies and traditions, including a tea ceremony, shakuhachi music, Japanese board games. Garden admission is free on Sunday as part of the Welcome to Back to Brooklyn celebration. Gallery hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; and free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds close. Information: (718) 623-7200.

QUEENS BOTANICAL GARDEN, 43-50 Main Street, Flushing. More than 39 acres devoted to woodland and bird, bee and perennial gardens. June blooms include rhododendrons, roses, iris, foxgloves and lavender. Free. Hours: daily, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 8 a.m. to 7 p.m.; closed Mondays. Garden admission is free. On weekends a trolley runs to Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Information: (718) 886-3800.
Zoos

BRONX ZOO, Bronx River Parkway and Fordham Road, Fordham. Some 265 wooded acres are devoted to naturalistic habitats, including Jungle World, African Plains, the Baboon Reserve, the World of Birds, the Aitken Sea Bird Colony (with daily penguin feedings at 3:30 p.m., weather permitting), Big Birds and the Congo Gorilla Forest. The Butterfly Zone has reopened through Oct. 1, with thousands of butterflies and moths and an area where visitors can see the metamorphosis of chrysalides, or cocoons, into butterflies or moths. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission, $9; $5 for children 2 to 12 and the elderly; free for everyone on Wednesdays. Parking: $6. Information: (718) 367-1010.

QUEENS ZOO, 53-51 111th Street, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. Animals include American bison, prairie dogs, pumas, elk, coyotes, cranes, spectacled bears and bobcats. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 271-1500.
ON THE STREET

SEVENTH BROADWAY SUMMER FESTIVAL, Broadway, from 66th to 72nd Streets, Manhattan. Antiques, food and crafts. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Project Open at Lincoln Towers, a social services agency.
UPPER MANHATTAN STREET FAIR, 116th Street from First to Park Avenues and Third Avenue from 106th to 122nd Streets. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.
STREET FESTIVAL, St. Stephen of Hungary Parish, East 82nd Street between First and York Avenues, Manhattan. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.
ANNUAL VILLAGE FAIR, Astor Place, from Broadway to Fourth Avenue, Greenwich Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Old St. Patrick's Cathedral School.

''BARGAINS IN BOOKS SALE,'' Brooklyn Heights Library, 280 Cadman Plaza West. Thousands of books from library shelves as well as outside contributions. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Sponsored by the Friends of the Brooklyn Heights Library.
PUERTO RICAN DAY PARADE, Fifth Avenue from 44th to 86th Streets, Manhattan. Sunday at noon.

EAST MANHATTAN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE GRAND AVENUE FESTIVAL, Grand Avenue, from 65th to 72nd Streets, Maspeth, Queens. With crafts, entertainment and rides. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Maspeth Chamber of Commerce.
CHRISTOPHER STREET FESTIVAL, from Seventh Avenue to Greenwich Avenue, West Village. Sunday, 11 a.m to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the Christopher East Block Association.

ANNUAL NYANA FESTIVAL, Battery Park, Lower Manhattan. A celebration of Jewish culture from the Soviet Union featuring performances, crafts and food. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Association for New Americans (Nyana).
NEW YORK CITY EXPO, Third Avenue from 23rd to 34th Streets, Manhattan. With crafts, food and entertainment. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Tilden Midtown Democratic Club.
EVENTS

MISSISSIPPI PICNIC, Central Park, East Meadow, Fifth Avenue at 97th Street, Manhattan. Featuring games, food and a tribute to Willie Morris, author of ''My Dog Skip'' and other works, who died last year. Tomorrow, noon to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the New York Society for the Preservation of Mississippi Heritage. Donations accepted; catfish lunch, $5 per person. Information: (718) 788-2988.

24TH AMERICAN CRAFTS FESTIVAL AT LINCOLN CENTER, Damrosch Park and the Josie L. Robertson Plaza. More than 400 crafts displays, as well as entertainment. Tomorrow, noon to 9 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. Also June 17-18, same hours.

WELCOME BACK TO BROOKLYN FESTIVAL, Grand Army Plaza, at the intersection of Flatbush Avenue and Eastern Parkway. Annual event with entertainment, food and crafts. Sunday, noon to 6 p.m. Related events include a free walking tour of Prospect Park at 2 p.m. sponsored by the Brooklyn Museum of Art (meets at the statue of John Stranahan, off Grand Army Plaza); and the Pathmark Multicultural Arts Festival, featuring performances of Middle Eastern and West Indian music. Sponsored by Brooklyn Information and Culture (BRIC). Information: (718) 855-7882; Web site; www.brooklynX.org.

HERITAGE DAY FESTIVAL, Eldridge Street Synagogue, 12 Eldridge Street, Lower East Side. With crafts, storytelling and entertainment. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission, $12; $6 for children under 12. Reservations: (212) 978-8800.

PARK SLOPE OPEN STUDIO TOUR, Brooklyn. A free, self-guided tour to the work spaces of more than 30 artists. Tomorrow and Sunday, 1 to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Working Artist Coalition (BWAC). Tour maps available at a variety of locations including Barnes and Noble, Seventh Avenue and Sixth Street, Park Slope. Information: (718) 596-2507.
WALKING TOURS

''HARLEM BAR HOP.'' A tour of night spots culminating in a jazz performance. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee, $20, plus drinks. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

''HELL AIN'T HOT: THIS HERE'S HELL'S KITCHEN,'' Manhattan. A historical look at this gritty area before its transformation into present-day Clinton. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the northwest corner of 10th Avenue and 42nd Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''GOTHAM CITY GHOST TOUR,'' Greenwich Village. Covers historic and infamous spots, including Edgar Allan Poe's home and the burial ground at Washington Square. Tomorrow at 5 p.m. and Sunday at 2:30 p.m.. Sponsored by N.Y.C. Discovery Tours. Fee, $12. Meeting place and reservations: (212) 465-3331.

''EDGAR ALLAN POE AND HIS GHOSTLY FRIENDS,'' Greenwich Village and the East Village. Explore the neighborhoods and learn about the ghosts of Edgar Allan Poe, Peter Stuyvesant and others. Meets Sunday at 2 and 6 p.m. outside the Second Avenue Deli, 156 Second Avenue, at 10th Street. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil's New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

GREENWICH VILLAGE AT TWILIGHT. Focuses on history and architecture, with stops at the Jefferson Market Library, St. Luke-in-the-Fields Church and the former residences of Aaron Burr, Edith Wharton and E. E. Cummings. Meets tomorrow at 5 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Fee: $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 439-1090.

''MEAT, MELVILLE AND INDUSTRIAL CHIC: THE TRANSFORMATION OF THE GANSEVOORT MARKET.'' A tour of the city's newest hot spot with an emphasis on the area's hidden gems and modern architectural adaptations. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m at the Chelsea Market, in front of Amy's Bread, Ninth Avenue between 15th and 16th Streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee: $15; $12 for society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

QUEENS JAZZ TRAIL. A bus and walking tour through the neighborhoods of Corona and Flushing and past the former homes of jazz greats, with lunch and a jazz concert. Meets tomorrow at 10 a.m. at Flushing Town Hall, 137-35 Northern Boulevard. Fee: $75; $65 for the elderly and $60 for students. Reservations necessary: (718) 463-7700, extension 222.

''SPLENDID GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL.'' A tour of the railroad station, which has undergone an extensive renovation. Stops include Vanderbilt Hall, the east staircase and the former site of a newsreel theater. Meets tomorrow at 12:30 p.m. on the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Lexington Avenue. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Fee: $5. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''ISLANDS OF GENTILITY: STUYVESANT SQUARE/GRAMERCY PARK,'' Manhattan. A look at two neighborhoods that retain the ambience of old New York. Meets on Sunday at 2 p.m. on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and East 14th Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A tour that includes stops at a church and several cultural institutions. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. on the southwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 116th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.

''THE BROADWAY THEATER DISTRICT: IT'S GOING TO BE A BUMPY NIGHT!'' Passes historic landmarks and classic movie and television sites in the district. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. in front of Holy Cross Church, 331 West 42nd Street, Clinton. Fee: $15. Sponsored by New York Curmudgeon Tours. Information and reservations: (212) 629-8813.

HARLEM AND THE BRONX. A tour of such Manhattan locations as Sugar Hill and the Morris-Jumel Mansion garden, followed by a trip to the Bronx for the Grand Concourse and Yankee Stadium. Sunday at 10:30 a.m. Led by Ed Botwin. Fee, $10, plus subway fare. Information and meeting place: (212) 769-1419.

BROOKLYN HEIGHTS. A tour of New York City's first landmark historic district, which contains more than 600 structures built before the Civil War. Meets on Sunday at 2 p.m. outside the Clark Street IRT subway station near the St. George Hotel on Clark Street, between Hicks and Henry Streets. Fee, $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''SEVENTH HARLEM MEER PERFORMANCE FESTIVAL,'' Central Park. A free two-month festival that runs from 4 to 6 p.m. on Sundays at the Charles A. Dana Discovery Center, Fifth Avenue and 110th Street. This weekend, the Bubba Brooks Quintet, a jazz group, will appear. Sponsored by the Central Park Conservancy. Information: (212) 860-1370.
